div.span: NO SCHOOL FOR STUDENTS UNTIL AT LEAST May 15, 2020 -- students have received learning materials for use at home

span.div: Due to the coronavirus/COVID-19 outbreak, school is closed until May 15, 2020 at the earliest. Food is being delivered daily along bus routes, and all students have materials for learning at home. Anyone age 18 and younger who is residing with a family having at least one child enrolled in our district can get food through TWO drive-up/walk-up sites, either the South Otselic or Georgetown schools, from 9 am - 11:30 am, Monday-Friday.INFO: Otselic Valley's Coronavirus (COVID-19) information page. Click here for frequent updates: https://www.ovcs.org/CoronavirusCOVID-19InformationPage.aspx

li.a: Otselic Valley Central School District Home
Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) Outbreak Information from the CDC
Otselic Valley Central School District Strategic Plan
Otselic Valley 2019-2020 Property Tax Report Card
Otselic Valley State of the District, March 2019

div.span:
IMPORTANT UPDATE from Mr. Robert Berson, Superintendent of Schools:
I want to let you know that there will be NO SCHOOL FOR STUDENTS ON MONDAY, MARCH 16. Monday will be a Superintendent's Conference Day for all staff as they continue to work on preparations in case school is closed for an extended period due to the coronavirus, or COVID-19.
At this time, it is expected that students and staff will report to school as usual on Tuesday, March 17, and will continue on a normal schedule until the Chenango County health department directs Otselic Valley to close school. If we are required to close, we will likely remain closed through the April break, returning April 14 at the earliest.
Please note that there are no confirmed cases of the novel coronavirus in our district at this time, but we remain in constant contact with authorities during this fluid situation. We are working with the most current information received, and will deal with rapid changes if needed. As I said in our staff meeting Friday afternoon, Otselic Valley is able to pivot quickly to meet challenges before us.
Because circumstances may change at any time, families are encouraged to begin planning for long-term closure, including child care.
Remember that carefully considered steps recommended by public health authorities will go a long way toward keeping our families and community healthy and calm. Learn more and stay updated through our website which now includes an updated coronavirus information page, social media, and robocalls. We will keep you informed.
Until then, no school for students on Monday, March 16.

h2.span: From the Chenango County Department of Health: Keeping Your Family Safe by Planning

div.strong: From the Chenango County Department of Health

span.div: Click here for the Chenango County Department of Health: https://www.co.chenango.ny.us/public-health/

em.strong: A COVID-19 outbreak in our community could last for a long time. Take time now to plan for your family's needs.

div.em: Create a household or family plan of action:

ul.li: Decide who will be included in your plans and what each person's needs would be. Keep in mind those family members who have health conditions; their health condition may worsen and the services that they routinely rely on might not be available if they become ill. Those at higher risk of getting very sick from this illness include: older adults (ages 60 and over) and people who have serious chronic medical conditions like heart disease, diabetes, and lung disease.
Identify community resources that might be needed for services or support. Consider organizations that provide mental health or counseling services, food, and other supplies.
Create an Emergency Contact List: a list of family, friends, neighbors, health care providers, school, employers, health department, and other community resources .

span.p: Choose a room in your home that can be used to separate a sick family member from those who are healthy. If possible there should be a separate bathroom for the person to use. Plan how these rooms will be cleaned as needed.

ul.li: Avoid contact with people who are sick
Stay at home while you are sick
Cover your cough and sneezes with a tissue
Clean and disinfect surfaces that are often touched (tables, doorknobs, countertops, and light switches) with household detergent and water

li.strong: Wash hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If soap is not available, use hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol

p.em: Prepare for extended school closures and possible changes at your workplace.

span.p: Talk to your employer about options for workers who are sick or who have to stay home to care for sick family.

p.em: Protect yourself and put your household plan into action:

ul.li: Stay home when you are sick with COVID-19 symptoms (fever, cough, difficulty breathing)
Keep away from other people who are sick, limiting contact with others as much as possible (about 6 feet)
Stay informed about the local COVID-19 situation from Chenango County Public Health or the New York State Department of Health

Continue practicing everyday preventive actions: Wash hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If soap is not available, use hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol. Cover your cough and sneezes with a tissue. Clean frequently touched surfaces and objects daily with regular detergent and water.
Use the separate room and bathroom you prepared for sick household members (if possible)
Notify your workplace if your schedule changes

p.em: If you or a family member are sick with COVID-19:

ul.li: Stay home except to get medical care; be sure to call ahead before visiting the doctor
Separate yourself from other people and animals in your home
Wear a facemask if you are sick and being transported to a medical facility; wear a facemask if you are caring for a person who is ill with COVID-19
Cover your coughs and sneezes
Clean your hands often
Avoid sharing personal household items, clean all "high-touch" surfaces daily
Monitor your symptoms

Call 911 if you have a medical emergency: if you have a medical emergency and need to call 911, notify the dispatch personnel that you have, or are being evaluated for, COVID-19. If possible, put on a face mask before emergency medical services arrive
Stay at home until instructed to leave

p.em: Review how effectively your plan worked:

ul.li: Did your plans for home, school, and work have you prepared?
Talk about any problems or issues you had and possible ways to improve your plan
Were there any additional resources that you could have used?
Join in on communty discussions. Let others know what worked for you and your family and learn from others what may work better next time.

Continue to practice everyday health habits and preventative actions. Stay home when you are sick, use good sneezing and coughing protocol, good hand washing, and frequently cleaning surfaces and objects.

Take care of the emotional health of your family. Share how you are feeling with others. Connect with family and friends. Help children cope after an outbreak by encouraging them to share their concerns and ask questions.
